Question 7: A 28-year-old man comes to get his power checked. The optometrist finds the focal length of 
his lens to be 0.75m; what will be its refractive power?
questions.explanation: Refractive power (dioptre) = 1/Focal length in metres So, for the given question, refractive power (D) = 1/0.75 = 1.33 D

questions.question:
Question 9: A 6-year-old child complains that she cannot see anything on the whiteboard clearly. On 
ophthalmological examination, she is found to have a 2 mm shortening of the axial length of 
the eyeball. How much eye power will this lead to?
questions.explanation:
Shortening of 2mm of the axial length of the eyeball will lead to 6D of hypermetropia. In axial hypermetropia, 1mm shortening of the anteroposterior diameter of the eye results in 3 
dioptres of hypermetropia. Therefore, 2-mm shortening will lead to 6D of hypermetropia. In curvature hypermetropia, a 1mm increase in radius of curvature results in 6 dioptres of 
hypermetropia.

questions.question:
Question 10: You are studying the optics of a patient with regular astigmatism. Identify the point at which 
the clearest image is formed? 26 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.explanation:
The given figure is a Sturm's conoid. It represents a bundle of light rays formed by a regularly 
astigmatic surface. The image is clearest or least confusing as point D, the circle of least 
confusion. When light passes through a regularly astigmatic surface(surface with toric curvature), vertical 
and horizontal rays converge at different points. The distance between the points of convergence (focus) of the vertical and horizontal rays is called 
the focal interval of strum. (distance between points B and F). The circle of least confusion/ circle 
of diffusion lies at the mid-point of this interval. For the given Sturm's conoid, • At point A, a horizontal oval is formed because vertical rays converge more rapidly than 
horizontal rays. • At point B, vertical rays come to a focus, while horizontal rays are still converging; so, it will be a 
horizontal straight line. • At points C, D, and E, the vertical rays are diverging and horizontal rays are still converging. 37 
Sold by @itachibot • At point D, the vertical rays have diverged as much as the horizontal rays have converged; so, we 
get a perfect circle called the circle of least confusion. • At point E, a vertical oval is formed. • At point F, a vertical straight line is formed • At point G and beyond, both rays are diverging, and we always get a vertical oval/prolate ellipse.

questions.question: Question 11: What is the Stiles-Crawford effect?

options.a: Cutting off of the peripheral rays by the iris
options.b: High refractive index of the core of nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex
options.c: Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina
options.d: More sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than the oblique rays

questions.explanation:
The Stiles–Crawford effect refers to the greater sensitivity of the retina to perpendicular rays than 
the oblique rays. It is one of the natural mechanisms that decrease aberration in the eye. The rays 
of light that enter through the center of the pupil have higher sensitivity as compared to those 
entering from the periphery of the pupil. Natural mechanisms that decrease aberrations in the human eye: • Cutting-off of the peripheral rays by the iris • The high refractive index of the core of the nucleus of the lens than that of the peripheral cortex • Low sensitivity of the peripheral retina • Stiles–Crawford effect

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following statements is false?

options.a: Rods and cones release Ach at their synapses.
options.d: Bipolar cells show either depolarization or hyperpolarization.

questions.explanation:
Rods and cones release glutamate (not acetylcholine) at their synapses. Photoreceptors get hyperpolarized in response to stimulus, and hence, phototransduction is 
associated with hyperpolarization. Amacrine cells secrete at least eight types of neurotransmitters, including GABA, glycine, 
dopamine, acetylcholine, and indolamine, all of which function as inhibitory neurotransmitters. Bipolar cells show both depolarization/hyperpolarization.
questions.chapter_heading: Elementary Optics and Physiology of Vision

questions.question: Question 16: Which of the following is responsible for inducing phototransduction?
questions.explanation:
Metarhodopsin II is responsible for phototransduction. It activates transducin member of G proteins. This leads to the closure of Na+ channels and 
hyperpolarization, thereby inducing phototransduction (signal transduction in the retina). 40

questions.question:
Question 17: During the dark phase of the visual cycle, which form of vitamin A combines with opsin to 
form rhodopsin?
questions.explanation: Opsin combines with 11-cis-retinal to produce rhodopsin. Only the retinal form of vitamin A is involved in the formation of the photopigment.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following statements is false regarding the physiology of photoreceptors?

options.a: Phototransduction results in closure of c-GMP-gated cation channels.
options.b: Chromophore regeneration occurs in the outer segment of photoreceptors.
options.c: Photon absorption induces photo-isomerisation of 11-cis-retinal to all-trans-retinal.
options.d: 11-cis-Retinal is bound to opsins by covalent bonds.

questions.explanation:
Chromophore regeneration occurs in the retinal pigment epithelial cells. Phototransduction: • Rhodopsin is a G-protein-coupled receptor found in the outer segments of rod photoreceptors. • 11-cis-retinal (a chromophore) is covalently bound to opsins via a lysine residue on one of the 
transmembrane domains. • The receptor is activated by photo-isomerization of prebound 11-cis-retinal to 
ALL-TRANS-retinal. • Activation of the receptor causes binding and activation of the G protein, transducin, with signal 
transduction via cGMP phosphodiesterase, resulting in a decrease in the intracellular cGMP levels 
and closure of the cGMP-gated Na channels. • This causes hyperpolarization of the photoreceptor cell, which modulates neurotransmitter 
release at the synapse with bipolar cells. • This entire process triggered by the activation of rhodopsin is phototransduction, which occurs 
in the outer segment of photoreceptors and converts light energy into an electrical signal. Chromophore regeneration: • All-trans retinAL is converted to all-trans-retinOL. 41 
Sold by @itachibot • All-trans-retinOL gets transported by interphotoreceptor retinoid-binding protein (IRBP) to the 
retinal pigment epithelial cells, where it is reconstituted into the 11-cis retinal isoform.

questions.question: Question 20: Which of the following statements is false regarding "blobs" in the primary visual cortex?

options.b: Are rich in the enzyme citrate synthase
options.c: Are present in layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex
options.d: Receive input from the interlaminar pathway

questions.explanation:
Blobs in the primary visual cortex are rich in the enzyme cytochrome oxidase. Blobs are sections of the visual cortex where groups of neurons that are sensitive to color 
assemble in cylindrical shapes. They are present in layers 2 and 3 of the visual cortex.

questions.question: Question 22: What is the visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum of the human eye?
questions.explanation:
The visible range of the electromagnetic spectrum for the human eye is 400–700 nm. Theories of color vision: • Trichromatic theory (Young–Helmholtz theory) assumes that there are three types of color 
receptors. Each receptor is assumed to respond to all wavelengths, however, each has different 
spectral sensitivities. • Opponent process theory, also known as the Hering theory, assumes three sets of receptor 
systems—red-green, blue-yellow, and black-white. Each one of these functions as an antagonistic 
pair (e.g., red light stimulates the red receptors and, at the same time, inhibits the green). • Edwin Land's theory has three separate color systems (retinexes). Each is an analog to a 
black-and-white picture. 44 
Sold by @itachibot
questions.chapter_heading: Elementary Optics and Physiology of Vision

questions.question: Question 23: What is the characteristic visual defect in deuteranomaly?
questions.explanation:
In deuteranomaly, the perception of green color is defective. It is the most common disorder of 
color vision. Monochromacy: Only one of the three primary colors (red, blue, or green) can be appreciated. Dichromacy: Two primary colors are appreciated. (anopia = absent). • Protanopia: Red color is not perceived. • Deuteranopia: Green color is not perceived. • Tritanopia: Blue color is not perceived. Trichromacy: All the three primary colors are appreciated, but one of them can be defective 
(anomaly = defective). • Protanomaly: Red color perception is defective. • Deuteranomaly: Green color perception is defective. • Tritanomaly: Blue color perception is defective. Achromatopsia: No color perception due to the absence of cones. It may also occur in the lesion of 
area V4 or V8 of the visual cortex. 45 
Sold by @itachibot

viewed from a distance of 6 meters?
questions.explanation:
The angle subtended by the optotype (individual letters on the chart) on the second line of 
Snellen’s chart in the above case would be 30 minutes of arc. The second line on Snellen’s chart corresponds to a distance of 36 meters. When viewed from a 
6m distance, it is denoted as visual acuity 6/36. Where, • The numerator (6) denotes the distance from which the patient is actually viewing it • The denominator (36) denotes the distance at which it should be ideally viewed. It denotes the 
distance at which each stroke of the letter would subtend the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) 
of one minute of arc. MAR = 1/Visual acuity Each letter is shaped such that it can be placed in a square, the sides of which are five times the 
breadth of individual limbs of the letters. Hence, the angle subtended by the optotype= MAR x 5 For eg: At exactly 6 meters distance from the patient, the letters on the 6/6 line shall subtend 5 
minutes of arc (such that the individual limbs of the letters subtend 1 minute of arc). The equation to calculate the minimum angle of resolution (MAR) is given as follows: For the given question, MAR = 1/ 6/36 MAR = 36/6 MAR = 6 minutes of arc Hence, the angle subtended by the entire letter is 6 × 5 = 30 minutes of arc. 47

questions.question:
Question 26: A 42-year-old man with monocular aphakia wears contact lenses. What is the approximate 
percentage of aniseikonia in his eyes?
questions.explanation:
The approximate percentage of aniseikonia in a person with monocular aphakia wearing a contact 
lens would be 8%. Aniseikonia is defined as the difference in image size between the two eyes and can lead to 
disturbances in stereopsis. The tolerable limit of aniseikonia is 5–8%. It is reduced with contact 
lens (8%) compared to glasses (25–30%) in aphakia. However, the percentage of aniseikonia is least with an intraocular lens (IOL) (1–3%), thus 
secondary IOL implantation is the most preferred management of unilateral aphakia.
questions.chapter_heading: Elementary Optics and Physiology of Vision

questions.question: Question 27: Which cerebellar nucleus controls the ocular saccade?
questions.explanation:
The Floccular nucleus of the cerebellum controls ocular saccades. A saccade is a rapid ballistic movement to change the point of fixation. It is the fastest of all eye 
movements and is initiated by the contralateral frontal lobe. Smooth pursuit is a slow tracking 
movement to keep the target on the fovea. It is controlled by the ipsilateral parieto-occipital lobe. Following an object from the right to left is left pursuit and is controlled by ipsilateral (left) 
parieto-occipital lobe, and the corrective movement is a saccade (in this case, left to right) termed 
right saccade and is controlled by the contralateral (left) frontal lobe. The floccular nucleus is found in the lobule HX of the cerebellar vermis. Its functions include 
matching pulse-step, gaze holding, and sustained smooth pursuit. Bilateral lesions of the flocculus 
result in the following: • Post-saccadic drift- saccadic movements do not stop, but there is a brief, several hundred 
milliseconds drift of the eyes after each saccade. • Saccadic pursuit- smooth tracking is replaced by simultaneous rapid jerking motions of the eye 
to follow an object toward the ipsilateral visual field. • Gaze-evoked nystagmus- impaired ability to hold the eyes in the eccentric position, resulting in 
gaze-evoked nystagmus towards the affected side of the cerebellum. Emboliform and globose nuclei: Generation of vertical saccades Fastigial nuclei: Pursuit initiation

questions.question: Question 30: What is the mean value for outflow facility of the aqueous in the normal eye?
questions.explanation:
The aqueous outflow facility is about 0.28 µL/min/mmHg. Aqueous humor is produced at an 
average rate of 2.0–2.5 µL/min. The ease with which the aqueous humor leaves the eye is called an aqueous outflow facility. • The outflow facility is measured using tonography. • The normal range is between 0.22–0.28 µL/min/mmHg. • A juxtacanalicular portion of the trabecular meshwork is the primary limiting factor for the 
outflow facility. • Uveoscleral outflow accounts for 10% of the total aqueous outflow facility. • Aqueous outflow facility decreases with aging. • Trabecular outflow facility is reduced in glaucoma. • Laser trabeculoplasty reduces intraocular pressure (IOP) in open-angle glaucoma by increasing 
the trabecular outflow facility. 49 
Sold by @itachibot Myopia and Hypermetropia
